sections.title: Understanding Percentages
sections.content:
PERCENTAGE means 'per hundred' or 'out of 100'. The symbol % represents 'per hundred'.

Key Concepts:
• 50% means 50 out of 100, or 50/100, or 0.5, or 1/2
• 100% means the whole amount
• 200% means twice the amount
• 0% means nothing

Why Use Percentages?
• Easy to compare different quantities
• Standard way to express proportions
• Universal understanding

Examples in Daily Life:
• Test scores: "I got 85% in Math"
• Sales: "50% off everything!"
• Taxes: "GST is 9% in Singapore"
• Interest: "Bank gives 2.5% interest per year"
• Statistics: "60% of students prefer online learning"

sections.title: Converting Forms
sections.content:
CONVERSION METHODS:

1. PERCENTAGE → DECIMAL
   Divide by 100 (move decimal point 2 places left)
   • 25% = 25 ÷ 100 = 0.25
   • 8% = 8 ÷ 100 = 0.08
   • 150% = 150 ÷ 100 = 1.50

2. DECIMAL → PERCENTAGE
   Multiply by 100 (move decimal point 2 places right)
   • 0.6 = 0.6 × 100 = 60%
   • 0.03 = 0.03 × 100 = 3%
   • 1.25 = 1.25 × 100 = 125%

3. PERCENTAGE → FRACTION
   Write as fraction over 100, then simplify
   • 40% = 40/100 = 2/5
   • 75% = 75/100 = 3/4
   • 12.5% = 12.5/100 = 125/1000 = 1/8

4. FRACTION → PERCENTAGE
   Convert to decimal, then to percentage
   • 3/5 = 0.6 = 60%
   • 7/8 = 0.875 = 87.5%
   • 2/3 = 0.666... = 66.67% (rounded)

Common Percentages to Remember:
• 1/2 = 50%
• 1/4 = 25%, 3/4 = 75%
• 1/5 = 20%, 2/5 = 40%, 3/5 = 60%, 4/5 = 80%
• 1/10 = 10%, 3/10 = 30%, 7/10 = 70%

sections.title: Finding Percentage of a Quantity
sections.explanation:
METHOD 1: Convert to decimal, then multiply
Find 30% of 80:
30% = 0.30
0.30 × 80 = 24

METHOD 2: Use fraction
Find 25% of 60:
25% = 25/100 = 1/4
1/4 × 60 = 15

METHOD 3: Break into parts
Find 15% of 200:
10% of 200 = 20
5% of 200 = 10 (half of 10%)
15% = 10% + 5% = 20 + 10 = 30

More Examples:
• 20% of 50 = 0.2 × 50 = 10
• 75% of 80 = 0.75 × 80 = 60
• 5% of 300 = 0.05 × 300 = 15
• 120% of 40 = 1.2 × 40 = 48

Quick Mental Math Tricks:
• 10% → divide by 10
• 50% → divide by 2
• 25% → divide by 4
• 5% → find 10%, then halve it

sections.title: Percentage Increase and Decrease
sections.content:
PERCENTAGE INCREASE:
New Value = Original + (Percentage × Original)
= Original × (1 + Percentage as decimal)

Example 1: Increase $50 by 20%
Method 1: 20% of 50 = 10, so 50 + 10 = $60
Method 2: 50 × 1.20 = $60

Example 2: Increase 80kg by 15%
15% of 80 = 12kg
80 + 12 = 92kg
OR: 80 × 1.15 = 92kg

PERCENTAGE DECREASE:
New Value = Original - (Percentage × Original)
= Original × (1 - Percentage as decimal)

Example 3: Decrease $200 by 30%
Method 1: 30% of 200 = 60, so 200 - 60 = $140
Method 2: 200 × 0.70 = $140

Example 4: Decrease 150m by 12%
12% of 150 = 18m
150 - 18 = 132m
OR: 150 × 0.88 = 132m

FINDING PERCENTAGE CHANGE:
Percentage Change = (Change/Original) × 100%

Example 5: Price changes from $40 to $50
Change = 50 - 40 = $10
Percentage increase = (10/40) × 100% = 25%

Example 6: Weight drops from 80kg to 72kg
Change = 80 - 72 = 8kg
Percentage decrease = (8/80) × 100% = 10%

sections.title: GST (Goods and Services Tax)
sections.content:
In Singapore, GST is 9% (as of 2024). It's added to most goods and services.

CALCULATING PRICE WITH GST:
Final Price = Original Price + (9% of Original Price)
= Original Price × 1.09

Example 1: Item costs $100 before GST
GST amount = 9% of 100 = $9
Price with GST = 100 + 9 = $109
OR: 100 × 1.09 = $109

Example 2: Meal costs $45 before GST
GST = 9% of 45 = $4.05
Total = 45 + 4.05 = $49.05
OR: 45 × 1.09 = $49.05

FINDING ORIGINAL PRICE (Before GST):
If total price (with GST) is given:
Original Price = Total Price ÷ 1.09

Example 3: Total bill is $218 (including GST)
Original price = 218 ÷ 1.09 = $200
GST amount = 218 - 200 = $18

Example 4: You paid $54.50 (with GST)
Original = 54.50 ÷ 1.09 = $50

REAL-WORLD TIP:
When you see prices in Singapore:
• "Price excludes GST" → need to add 9%
• "GST-inclusive" or "Inclusive of GST" → already included
• Always check the receipt to see GST breakdown!

sections.title: Discounts and Sale Prices
sections.content:
DISCOUNT means reduction in price, usually shown as a percentage.

CALCULATING SALE PRICE:
Sale Price = Original - Discount
= Original × (1 - Discount%)

Example 1: $80 item with 25% discount
Discount = 25% of 80 = $20
Sale price = 80 - 20 = $60
OR: 80 × 0.75 = $60 (since 100% - 25% = 75%)

Example 2: $150 jacket, 40% off
Discount = 40% of 150 = $60
Sale = 150 - 60 = $90
OR: 150 × 0.60 = $90

MULTIPLE DISCOUNTS:
Apply one after another, NOT by adding percentages!

Example 3: $100 item with "20% off + additional 10% off"
After 1st discount: 100 × 0.80 = $80
After 2nd discount: 80 × 0.90 = $72
Final price: $72
NOTE: This is NOT 30% off! (that would be $70)

SINGAPORE SALE TERMS:
• "50% off" = half price
• "Buy 1 Get 1 Free" = 50% off total
• "$50 off for purchases above $100" = fixed amount discount
• "Additional 20% off marked price" = apply to already reduced price

FINDING DISCOUNT PERCENTAGE:
Discount% = (Discount Amount/Original Price) × 100%

Example 4: Original $200, now $140
Discount = 200 - 140 = $60
Discount% = (60/200) × 100% = 30%

sections.title: Profit, Loss and Markup
sections.content:
PROFIT: When selling price > cost price
Profit = Selling Price - Cost Price
Profit% = (Profit/Cost Price) × 100%

Example 1: Buy for $60, sell for $80
Profit = 80 - 60 = $20
Profit% = (20/60) × 100% = 33.33%

LOSS: When selling price < cost price
Loss = Cost Price - Selling Price
Loss% = (Loss/Cost Price) × 100%

Example 2: Buy for $50, sell for $40
Loss = 50 - 40 = $10
Loss% = (10/50) × 100% = 20%

FINDING SELLING PRICE:
With profit: SP = CP × (1 + Profit%)
With loss: SP = CP × (1 - Loss%)

Example 3: Cost $120, want 25% profit
SP = 120 × 1.25 = $150

Example 4: Cost $80, willing to accept 15% loss
SP = 80 × 0.85 = $68

FINDING COST PRICE:
From profit: CP = SP ÷ (1 + Profit%)
From loss: CP = SP ÷ (1 - Loss%)

Example 5: Sold for $90 at 20% profit
CP = 90 ÷ 1.20 = $75

MARKUP:
Retailers add markup to cost to set selling price.
Marked Price = Cost + (Markup% × Cost)

Example 6: Shop buys at $40, adds 60% markup
Marked price = 40 × 1.60 = $64
sections.content_zh:
盈利：当售价>成本价
盈利 = 售价 - 成本价
盈利% = (盈利/成本价) × 100%

例1：$60买入，$80卖出
盈利 = 80 - 60 = $20
盈利% = (20/60) × 100% = 33.33%

亏损：当售价<成本价
亏损 = 成本价 - 售价
亏损% = (亏损/成本价) × 100%

例2：$50买入，$40卖出
亏损 = 50 - 40 = $10
亏损% = (10/50) × 100% = 20%

求售价：
有盈利：售价 = 成本价 × (1 + 盈利%)
有亏损：售价 = 成本价 × (1 - 亏损%)

例3：成本$120，想要25%盈利
售价 = 120 × 1.25 = $150

例4：成本$80，愿意接受15%亏损
售价 = 80 × 0.85 = $68

求成本价：
从盈利：成本价 = 售价 ÷ (1 + 盈利%)
从亏损：成本价 = 售价 ÷ (1 - 亏损%)

例5：以20%盈利卖出$90
成本价 = 90 ÷ 1.20 = $75

加价：
零售商在成本上加价以设定售价。
标价 = 成本 + (加价% × 成本)

例6：商店以$40购入，加价60%
标价 = 40 × 1.60 = $64

sections.title: Simple Interest
sections.content:
SIMPLE INTEREST: Money earned on savings or charged on loans.

Formula: I = (P × R × T) / 100
Where:
• I = Interest
• P = Principal (initial amount)
• R = Rate per year (%)
• T = Time (in years)

Total Amount = Principal + Interest

Example 1: Deposit $1000 at 3% per year for 2 years
I = (1000 × 3 × 2) / 100
I = 6000 / 100 = $60
Total = 1000 + 60 = $1060

Example 2: Borrow $5000 at 5% per year for 3 years
I = (5000 × 5 × 3) / 100
I = 75000 / 100 = $750
Total to repay = 5000 + 750 = $5750

Example 3: How long to earn $120 interest on $2000 at 4%?
I = (P × R × T) / 100
120 = (2000 × 4 × T) / 100
120 = 80T
T = 120 ÷ 80 = 1.5 years

Example 4: What rate gives $150 interest on $1500 in 2 years?
150 = (1500 × R × 2) / 100
150 = 30R
R = 150 ÷ 30 = 5%

REAL APPLICATION:
Banks in Singapore typically offer 0.05% to 3% interest on savings.
Credit card interest can be 24% per year or more!
Always compare rates before borrowing or saving.
